    <script type="text/javascript">

      // store the original cookie setter and getter
      document.cookieSetter = Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor(Document.prototype, 'cookie').set;
      document.cookieGetter = Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor(Document.prototype, 'cookie').get;

      // each item in this array is in the format [cookie, group]
      var notConsentedButTriedToLoad = [];
      function OptanonWrapper() {
        var onetrustData = OneTrust.GetDomainData();
        var consentedGroups = OptanonActiveGroups;
        var cookies = {};

        // create one object full of all of the cookies in the config for easy for quick lookups
        onetrustData.Groups.forEach(function (group) {
          group.Cookies.forEach(function (cookie) {
            cookies[cookie.Name] = { group: group.OptanonGroupId };
          });
        });

        // override the cookie setter with our new function
        document.__defineSetter__("cookie", setCookie);
        document.__defineGetter__("cookie", document.cookieGetter);

        function setCookie(cookie) {
          if (!cookie) return;
          var cookieArr = cookie.split("=");
          if (!cookieArr.length) return;
          var cookieName = cookieArr[0];

          // Don't set cookies that dont exist in the OneTrust config
          if (!cookies[cookieName]) {
            return;
          }

          // get the group this cookie belongs to
          var cookieGroup = cookies[cookieName].group;

          // Don't set cookies that don't have User consent
          // but let it set the cookie if we know it's required
          // but store the value so we can set them if Onetrust consent changes
          if (consentedGroups.indexOf(cookieGroup) === -1) {
            notConsentedButTriedToLoad.push([cookie, cookieGroup]);
            return;
          }

          // set the cookie using the original javascript cookie setter
          document.cookieSetter(cookie);
        }

        // When the user changes their consent, we should set the cookies that were previously blocked
        OneTrust.OnConsentChanged(function(e) {
          var newConsentedGroups = e.detail;
          notConsentedButTriedToLoad.forEach(function(cookieDetails) {
            var cookie = cookieDetails[0];
            var cookieGroup = cookieDetails[1];

            // cookie is in the new list of consented groups, so we can set it now
            if (newConsentedGroups.indexOf(cookieGroup) > -1) {
              document.cookieSetter(cookie);
            }
          })
        })
      }
    </script>

	<meta property="og:description" content="Need to make a form for a mailing list? We’ve got it. How about a form for collecting online payments? Oh yeah, we’ve got one too. From employment application forms to contact us forms, our creative geniuses here at Wufoo have pretty much thought of it all. The forms contain fields to collect contact information, they have fill-in sections where people can leave comments, and you can customize drop-down sections or and even include a map. Browse our extensive online form collection. We know you’ll find one that’s perfect for your needs!">

			<div class="container container--centered">
				<h1 class="h3">Wufoo Forms Gallery: Forms</h1>

				<p>We have done the hard work for you so that you can get a head start on data collection.<br>Are you ready to create a form? Let's go!</p>

				<div class="m-templates__description">
				<p>Need to make a form for a mailing list? We’ve got it. How about a form for collecting online payments? Oh yeah, we’ve got one too. From employment application forms to contact us forms, our creative geniuses here at Wufoo have pretty much thought of it all. The forms contain fields to collect contact information, they have fill-in sections where people can leave comments, and you can customize drop-down sections or and even include a map. Browse our extensive online form collection. We know you’ll find one that’s perfect for your needs!</p>
				</div>

Best Web Form Examples to Draw Inspiration From

Even when the internet continually evolves to meet the ever-changing needs of its users, one thing remains constant: the pivotal role of online web forms.

Whether it's signing up for a service, providing feedback, or making a purchase, web forms play a crucial role in gathering information and facilitating user actions.

Yet, the path to designing an effective and user-friendly web form can seem like a daunting journey.

To help you in this endeavor, we've compiled a list of the latest web form design examples across various categories. These examples not only demonstrate excellent design but also provide inspiration for your web forms that can get unparalleled user interaction.

Table of content

● Different Website Form Examples
1. Signup Web Form Examples
2. Login Web Form Examples
3. Product Landing Page Website Form Examples
4. Subscription Web Form Examples
5. Event Registration Web Form Examples
6. Check-out Web Form Examples
7. Questionnaire Web Form Examples
8. Feedback/Survey Web Form Examples
9. Free Trial Web Form Examples
10. Contact Us Web Form Examples
11. Blog Conversion Web Form Example
● Get Inspired By Your Favorite Website Form Examples

Different Website Form Examples

1. Signup Web Form Examples

A user-friendly signup form is crucial for attracting and retaining users. Airbnb's signup form is an outstanding example.

It focuses on simplicity and ease of use. When users sign up on Airbnb, they are only asked for essential information like their name, email address, and password. The multi-step form has a clean and uncluttered layout, which helps users quickly understand what is required.

One notable feature is real-time validation feedback. As users enter their information, the form provides immediate feedback, such as checking the strength of the password or validating the email address format. This real-time guidance helps users complete the signup process smoothly and free of any error.
SignUp Now

2. Login Web Form Examples

The login form is often the first interaction users have with your business website. Slack's login form sets an impressive standard that offers both manual and automated ways of signing in.

It features a clear and inviting design, with a focus on usability. The form only includes necessary fields along with different sign-in options and useful links.

The form uses security measures such as password protection to protect user data. The colors are also muted and relaxing, which helps to create a calming and inviting atmosphere.

3. Product Landing Page Website Form Examples

Product landing pages often include forms to capture leads or demo requests since it is where most of your hot leads might land. Salesforce's product landing page are perfect example of landing page forms.

They are designed to be as concise as possible, while still collecting the information that Salesforce needs to qualify leads. The form is also designed to be mobile-friendly so that potential customers can fill it out from their smartphones or tablets.

The forms are easy to use and understand, with clear instructions, visuals that provide more information to the visitors, and helpful labels. The forms are also mobile-friendly so that potential customers can fill them out from their smartphones or tablets.

4. Subscription Web Form Examples

Subscription forms are essential for building a loyal customer base and streamlining the sales process. Netflix's subscription form demonstrates a straightforward approach for its users to keep enjoying the service without going through much trouble to subscribe or renew the service.

The form's sleek and straightforward design, with a prominently displayed call-to-action (CTA) button, encourages users to subscribe. It requests minimal information from users.

First, users are asked to choose a plan simply - no typing required, just a click. Then they only need to enter their email and password. And finally, the users have to set up their preferred payment method. An easy and seamless experience to subscribe to.

5. Event Registration Web Form Examples

Event registration forms are designed to collect data quickly and to create a smooth experience for the registrants without confusing or distracting them. So, they need to be intuitive simple, and efficient.

Zoom's event registration form is short and straightforward, with a focus on collecting the essential information from registrants. The form is well-designed and uses a consistent color scheme.

The form uses security measures such as password protection to protect user data with concise instructions and helpful labels to guide users.

6. Check-out Web Form Examples

Websites rely heavily on checkout forms and you would never want your users to bounce from there, so your checkout form design should cover everything the user might want to know.

ERDEM’S checkout form is an excellent example of a well-designed form with all necessary user concerns. It features a clear order summary and an uncluttered layout that is easy to understand, along with breadcrumbs that outline the various steps involved in the process.

Customers can take advantage of quick checkout options such as ShopPay, PayPal, and GPay, making the payment process smoother. Additionally, the checkout page allows users to apply promo codes or gift cards for added convenience.

7. Questionnaire Web Form Examples

Questionnaires require a thoughtful design to encourage user participation while making it easier to fill in the questions without feeling overwhelmed.

Red Bull's quiz form design is simple and engaging, with a focus on creating a fun and interactive experience for users. The form is divided into two main sections: the quiz itself and the results page.

The quiz section is made up of a series of multiple-choice questions about Red Bull. The questions are all related to the brand's products, history, and culture. The questions are presented in a visually appealing way, with colorful graphics and clear text.

The results page is where users can see their scores and learn more about their results. The page also includes options to learn more about the product to spike user’s interest.

8. Feedback/Survey Web Form Examples

Feedback and survey forms are vital for gathering user opinions. Braintree has a no-fuss, easy-to-read, and easy-to-fill survey web form.

The form uses a simple and modern design with clear fonts and colors. It is also mobile and table-friendly so users can easily fill the form.
The form also includes a thank you message to show appreciation for respondents' time and effort after the form is submitted.

9. Free Trial Web Form Examples

Free trial forms are important, especially for SaaS companies as most prospects would like to out the service before committing. These forms also help you learn more about their requirement to be able to guide them better and convert them.

HubSpot's free trial landing page & form is a standout example. It effectively highlights the benefits of signing up for a free trial and provides a clear CTA to the free trial form to help users get started.

Users are prompted to enter their information, and the form's design and content emphasize the value they will receive during the trial period. This encourages more users to take advantage of the free trial offer.

10. Contact Us Web Form Examples

Last but not the least – the "Contact Us" form might not gain much spotlight but is super important as it acts as the gateway for user inquiries and serves your customers better.

Zendesk's contact page happens to be one of the best designs to get inspired from.

It stands out with its clean design and straightforward fields. It offers two clear CTAs on leads to the product & knowledge base while clicking the other opens up the Contact Us form.

The web form has a minimalistic design and necessary fields and real-time email verification to ensure that there is no error while submitting the form and that the user is easily reachable.

11. Blog Conversion Web Form Example

The above-mentioned blog conversion form example derives from the blog section of the Bookatrekking company. It covers a popular destination route named Alta via 1 that is described in all the details in an educative tone.

At the top of the page, you can spot a trek finder form that will permit you to find any track as fast as possible. The functionality of an educative blog and the fast search serves as a great sample of the successful implementation of blog conversion by trekking professionals.

Get Inspired By Your Favorite Website Form Examples

These website form examples showcase the importance of thoughtful design and a user-centric approach when creating web forms. By studying these examples, you can gain valuable insights and inspiration for your web forms.

Remember that a well-designed web form can improve user experience, increase conversions, and ultimately lead to the success of your website or application.

So, take the time to analyze and draw inspiration from your favorite website form examples to create forms that are not only aesthetically pleasing but also highly functional and user-friendly.

How to Create an Online Form

FormSmarts allows anyone to create a form quickly and easily with our interactive online form builder. The video below shows how to build a simple contact form. Follow the detailed instructions in this guide to create a more complex form, such as a survey or online membership form.

Advanced topics of the form builder like payment integration, form attachments and email recipient management are outside of the scope of this document. Visit the Help section of the website for an extensive coverage of these topics.

Create a Form

To create a form, visit the form builder section of the website. You can access the form builder with the My Forms link at the top right-hand corner of every page. The form builder will walk you through the three steps needed to generate a fully functional web form in minutes and add it to your site:

  1. Choose a name and title for the form in the Forms tab of the form builder
  2. Add input fields to the form in the Fields tab of the form builder
  3. Grab the form's URL or embedding code to integrate the form onto your site

Sign In to FormSmarts

First, sign in to the online form builder using the email address registered on your account and your password. If you haven't got an account yet, create an account now. Make sure you visit the link in the email message we'll send you to activate your account. You won't be able to log in unless your account has been activated.

You are now ready to create an online form.
  1. Enter a friendly form name, for your own use
  2. Enter a title for your new form. The title should be short and descriptive.
  3. Next, optionally enter a return URL. This is the URL (i.e. web address) on your website where users will be sent to after the form has been submitted.
  4. Finally, you may optionally add form filling instructions. Any text you enter will appear at the top of the form. Instructions may include links and basic formatting.

Hit the Create Form button.

Add Input Fields

You now need to populate the form with input fields, where users will be able to enter information.

Notice that we've now switched to the Fields tab of the form builder. The Fields tab lists all fields attached to the form, and allows you add new fields, edit fields, and change the order fields appear on the form.

To add fields:

  1. First, select an input widget. If you are building a simple contact form you will only need single-line Text Boxes (i.e. HTML text control) and multi-line Text Areas (i.e. HTML textarea). FormSmarts also supports the other types of HTML form input fields for users creating more complex online forms. You'll find advice on choosing the correct input field below.
  2. Enter a field name. This is the name/label of the input field like First Name or Email. This may also be a question e.g. How would you rate the service?
  3. Next, for text boxes only, choose which content form users are allowed to enter in the field. For example, you should select Email for an email field and Positive Number for somebody's weight. This defines which characters and format are accepted in that input field. Selecting the correct type is important to allow form validaton. Refer to the table below for guidance. Note that the form builder can often automatically pre-select the relevant Allowed Content based on the field's name.
  4. Specify whether the field is optional or not. Users won't be able to submit the form without providing a value for all required input fields.
  5. Last, optionally enter a field description. The description should indicate the field's intended content to help the user. For example, the description of a “Message” field could be “Your message to the webmaster”.

Now that you've added input fields, the form is fully operational. You can try it, publish it online and start using it.

Want to collect form entries on FormSmarts and download an aggregated Excel report? Remember to enable form data storage for each of your form!

Field Data Types (aka ‘Allowed Content’) Reference Table

Data TypeExample UseDescription
Letters person's name, profession Field may only contain letters A to Z, spaces, and hyphens “-”
Letters + Numbers postal address, zip code, phone number Field may only contain letters, numbers, commas, question marks, spaces, and hyphens “-”
Email email address A single email address
URL URL A single (URL) web address. Only HTTP is currently supported for the protocol part of the URL.
Positive Integer number of items purchased, age, year Up to 9223372036854775807
Number price Any valid number, positive or negative, up to 9999999.99
Date date of birth, booking date A valid date. Displays a date picker.
Phone Number phone or fax number Any local or international phone number.
Country a country Shows the standard list of countries. Note that the country of residence of the visitor is automatically pre-selected.
Any Text comment Any alpha-numeric character and punctuation. Only use this input field type when no other type applies.

How to Edit a Form

To edit a form, visit the Forms Tab of the form builder and click or tap the pen icon corresponding to the form you want to modify. The Form Details screen of a form lets you change all its properties.

The Basic Settings tab allows you to edit a form's name, title, form filling instructions and category.

Visit the Submit Actions tab to change the destination emails of the form, stop or resume storing form responses on FormSmarts for online access and export to excel, and change the form's email routing policy.

The Submit Actions tab also allows you to change the main action performed when a form is submitted: from simply showing a confirmation (thank you) message — the default, to collecting a payment (integrate with PayPal) or redirecting the user to your website.

This is also where you would change a form's return URL and confirmation message, and edit the text of the confirmation email sent by FormSmarts when a payment form is submitted and paid.

Head to the Layout & Colors tab to switch form layouts and change the colors of a form and of its buttons.

How to Duplicate a Form

You can create a copy of a form in the Forms Tab of the Form Builder:
  1. Select the form you would like to copy in the list
  2. Click the duplicate button in the upper-right hand corner of the Form Builder, as illustrated below.

How to Delete a Form

You may delete a form in the Forms tab. Click on the icon corresponding to the form you wish to remove, and confirm. Deleted forms cannot be recovered and all stored entries and form attachments will also be delete. If you only need to temporarily suspend a form, disable it as explained in the next section.

How to Temporarily Disable a Form

If you're using an online form to take registrations for a yearly event (or for that matter, any non-continuous process), you will want to disable the form after the closing date until the next event. Use the pause button to disable a form and the start button to restore it. Changes will appear immediately on your website. When a form is accessed while disabled, an error message is shown stating that the form has been suspended by its owner.

Editing, Reordering & Deleting Fields

Editing an Input Field

To edit the details of a field, visit the Fields tab of the form builder and click on the icon corresponding to the field you wish to modify.

For each of field, the Field Details screen lets you change all field properties. The form's name, description, data type, widget, and optional status can all be changed from that page.

Reordering Fields

You may sometimes need to change the order in which input fields appear on a form. In the list of fields, use drag & drop to move each field to the position you want.

Deleting a Field

To remove an individual field, visit the Fields tab, and lick on the trash can icon corresponding to the field you wish to delete.

Publish Your Forms

Because FormSmarts hosts your forms, publishing a form is as easy as posting a link. We give you two options to let your visitors access your forms: embedding and linking.

Embedding a Form on a Page of Your Site

To embed forms on your website, simply copy the code snippet given in the Forms tab of the form builder into the HTML source of a page of your site. You will then need to upload that page to your web server in the usual way.

Note that if you embed a form on your website:

  • we won't be able to automatically adapt the form layout to the different types of browsers and devices, like cellphones & mobile devices and regular desktop browsers
  • your form will not be available if your site is down or slow
For these reasons, the embedding option is not always recommended.

Sharing a Form URL Online

Alternatively, you can simply post the FormSmarts-provided form URL or shortened URL anywhere you want on the web:
  • use the form URL to place a link on your website or blog
  • share a link on Twitter, Facebook, etc.
  • use the form on ebay to communicate with potential sellers
  • include the form URL in emails (restrictions apply)

Sharing a Form Offline

FormSmarts provides a QR code for each form in the Form Publishing Options screen of the form builder:
  • Add the QR code on posters and documents so users can scan it with their phone and directly access the form
  • Also print the form's shortened URL on paper documents

Review Optional Settings

You may optionally customize your web forms in the Settings tab of the form builder.

Setting the Destination Email Address of a Form

When you make a new form, it sent to your login email address by default. If you would like form responses to be sent to a different email address or want to have them sent to multiple email recipients, you will first need to add the email addresses to your account. You will then be able to change the recipients of a particular form in the Forms tab of the form builder.

Setting a Form Owner Name

You can increase form users trust and confidence by verifying the ownership of your site. FormSmarts will then display your verified site URL on your forms.

Brand Your Forms

We advise you to brand your forms with your own logo whenever your visitors will be accessing forms by their FormSmarts URL. Your logo will then be displayed in the top left corner of your forms, thus increasing their visual appeal and user recognition.

Choosing the Right Form Control

Part of designing effective an form is selecting the right input field widget, a.k.a form controls. Here are some tips to help you choose.

Text Field

  • Use a text input field when you expect a short, one line answer
  • Example use: name, email

Text Area

  • Use a textarea for open questions, or when you expect a long, multi-line answer
  • Example use: comment, message

Radio Botton

  • Use radio-buttons to provide a range of predefined values
  • Example: rating (good, average, bad)
  • For more than three or four options, a drop-down list may be more suitable
  • Can be used for yes/no questions instead of a checkbox
  • If the field is optional, the first item of the list is selected by default

Drop-Down List

  • Use a drop-down list (HTML select field) to provide a range of predefined answers
  • Example: referral/how did you find us?
  • Use preferably if there are many options, or if the description of each option spans several words
  • Do not use for yes/no questions
  • We currently do not support multiple selections. Use checkboxes instead if you need multiple selections.
  • If the field is optional, the first item of the list is selected by default

Checkbox

  • Use for statements the user must agree to
  • If the the check box is mandatory (i.e. not optional), the user won't be able to submit the form unless the box is checked
  • Example use: Subscribe to the newsletter
  • You can use radio-buttons instead to give more weight to the choice
  • Checkboxes are unchecked by default
  • If you want to ask a question and provide a list of options for the answer, use a checkbox list instead.

Checkbox List

  • Use a check-box list to provide a question with a list of yes/no answers (i.e. checked/unchecked) where the user may select multiple answers
  • If the check-box list is set as optional, users will be able to submit the form without selecting any answers
  • If the check-box list is required (i.e. not optional), users will not be able to proceed unless they have checked at least one box in the list
  • Checkboxes are unchecked by default.

Form Attachment

  • The file upload widget allows users to attach a picture or document to a form.

Electronic Signature

  • The electronic signature widget allows a user to sign a form online.

Agreement

  • Use an agreement widget when you need the person filling out a form to agree to a (usually lengthy) statement on a form
  • Good for waivers, liability releases, contracts (terms & conditions, privacy statement) and policies
  • Users can read the agreement document in a scrollable area on the form, pop it out to a larger window or read it full screen as needed.

          <span id="hs_cos_wrapper_post_body" class="hs_cos_wrapper hs_cos_wrapper_meta_field hs_cos_wrapper_type_rich_text" style="" data-hs-cos-general-type="meta_field" data-hs-cos-type="rich_text"><p>In recent years, I feel a bit spoiled when it comes to filling out online forms -- typically, they’re able to auto-fill my information, and take less than a minute to get me what I need.</p><div class="blog-post-body-featured-image"><img src="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_7.webp?width=595&height=400&name=form-examples_7.webp" alt="web-form-best-examples" width="595" height="400" srcset="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_7.webp?width=298&height=200&name=form-examples_7.webp 298w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_7.webp?width=595&height=400&name=form-examples_7.webp 595w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_7.webp?width=893&height=600&name=form-examples_7.webp 893w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_7.webp?width=1190&height=800&name=form-examples_7.webp 1190w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_7.webp?width=1488&height=1000&name=form-examples_7.webp 1488w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_7.webp?width=1785&height=1200&name=form-examples_7.webp 1785w" sizes="(max-width: 595px) 100vw, 595px"></div>
<!--more-->
<p>Forms used to require so much information, you’d have to really, <em>really </em>want something to dedicate the time to filling one out.</p>
<p>Now, we notice immediately if a form is cumbersome or time-consuming -- because so many forms aren’t. If a form doesn’t almost instantaneously get us what we want, we ditch the page.</p>
<p>Here, we’ve collected some of the most impressive online forms so you can learn by example, and hopefully apply some of these methods to your own web forms moving forward.</p>
<p><!--HubSpot Call-to-Action Code --><span class="hs-cta-wrapper" id="hs-cta-wrapper-d8b6ce89-2583-4f2a-8dd0-6a9c64f582b5"><span class="hs-cta-node hs-cta-d8b6ce89-2583-4f2a-8dd0-6a9c64f582b5" id="hs-cta-d8b6ce89-2583-4f2a-8dd0-6a9c64f582b5" style="visibility: visible;"><!--[if lte IE 8]><div id="hs-cta-ie-element"></div><![endif]--><a href="https://cta-redirect.hubspot.com/cta/redirect/53/d8b6ce89-2583-4f2a-8dd0-6a9c64f582b5" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img class="hs-cta-img" id="hs-cta-img-d8b6ce89-2583-4f2a-8dd0-6a9c64f582b5" style="border-width:0px;margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px" height="59" width="565" src="https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/d8b6ce89-2583-4f2a-8dd0-6a9c64f582b5.png" alt="Download Now: The Ultimate Guide to Web Forms [Free Ebook]" align="middle"></a></span><script charset="utf-8" src="/hs/cta/cta/current.js" nonce=""></script><script type="text/javascript" nonce=""> hbspt.cta._relativeUrls=true;hbspt.cta.load(53, 'd8b6ce89-2583-4f2a-8dd0-6a9c64f582b5', {"useNewLoader":"true","region":"na1"}); </script></span><!-- end HubSpot Call-to-Action Code --></p>
<h3>1. <a href="https://www.kickstarter.com/" rel="noopener" target="_blank">Kickstarter</a></h3>
<p>Kickstarter’s sign-up form is clean, with a basic white background, so you can focus on the form fields that matter. It also doesn’t ask for too much information, which is key for holding the attention of a busy audience.</p>
<div><img src="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_2.webp?width=319&height=488&name=form-examples_2.webp" width="319" height="488" loading="lazy" alt="web form examples: Kickstarter" style="width: 319px; display: block; margin: 0px auto; height: auto; max-width: 100%;" srcset="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_2.webp?width=160&height=244&name=form-examples_2.webp 160w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_2.webp?width=319&height=488&name=form-examples_2.webp 319w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_2.webp?width=479&height=732&name=form-examples_2.webp 479w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_2.webp?width=638&height=976&name=form-examples_2.webp 638w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_2.webp?width=798&height=1220&name=form-examples_2.webp 798w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_2.webp?width=957&height=1464&name=form-examples_2.webp 957w" sizes="(max-width: 319px) 100vw, 319px"></div>
<h3>2. <a href="https://www.houseoffraser.co.uk/">House of Fraser</a></h3>
<p>House of Fraser’s form is enticingly easy, with a pull-down menu to select delivery methods and columns like “collection or delivery” and “payment and billing”, so you can see where you are in the process. Best of all, the form incorporates the option for live chat. If a buyer is having concerns or doubts, it’s useful to have the ability to get clarification within the form itself without leaving the page.</p>
<p><img src="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_11.webp?width=700&height=515&name=form-examples_11.webp" width="700" height="515" loading="lazy" alt="web form examples: House of Fraser" style="width: 700px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; height: auto; max-width: 100%;" srcset="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_11.webp?width=350&height=258&name=form-examples_11.webp 350w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_11.webp?width=700&height=515&name=form-examples_11.webp 700w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_11.webp?width=1050&height=773&name=form-examples_11.webp 1050w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_11.webp?width=1400&height=1030&name=form-examples_11.webp 1400w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_11.webp?width=1750&height=1288&name=form-examples_11.webp 1750w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_11.webp?width=2100&height=1545&name=form-examples_11.webp 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px"></p>
<h3>3. <a href="https://www.staples.com/">Staples</a></h3>
<p>A guest checkout option is often imperative to ensure anyone can buy your product, with or without an account. If someone is in a rush, they might become frustrated by a lengthy “Create Account” form, and abandon their efforts. Staples understands the necessity of guest checkout, and finds a way to include it without losing too many new account owners to that option -- underneath their "New Customer" field, they outline benefits to creating an account versus guest checkout. Creating an easier new customer sign-up is an effective way to convert more users into account owners.</p>
<div><img src="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_4.webp?width=700&height=453&name=form-examples_4.webp" width="700" height="453" loading="lazy" alt="web form examples: Staples" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; height: auto; max-width: 100%; width: 700px;" srcset="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_4.webp?width=350&height=227&name=form-examples_4.webp 350w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_4.webp?width=700&height=453&name=form-examples_4.webp 700w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_4.webp?width=1050&height=680&name=form-examples_4.webp 1050w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_4.webp?width=1400&height=906&name=form-examples_4.webp 1400w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_4.webp?width=1750&height=1133&name=form-examples_4.webp 1750w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_4.webp?width=2100&height=1359&name=form-examples_4.webp 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px"></div>
<h3>4. <a href="https://leadformly.com/">Leadformly</a></h3>
<p>I’m willing to bet when you see only one question, you’re more willing to fill it out than if you were shown a long list. By keeping it to one field box at a time and creating a progress icon at the bottom, Leadformly likely mitigates the amount of users who leave the page before completion.</p>
<div><img src="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_10.webp?width=700&height=281&name=form-examples_10.webp" width="700" height="281" loading="lazy" alt="web form examples: Leadformly" style="height: auto; max-width: 100%; width: 700px;" srcset="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_10.webp?width=350&height=141&name=form-examples_10.webp 350w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_10.webp?width=700&height=281&name=form-examples_10.webp 700w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_10.webp?width=1050&height=422&name=form-examples_10.webp 1050w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_10.webp?width=1400&height=562&name=form-examples_10.webp 1400w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_10.webp?width=1750&height=703&name=form-examples_10.webp 1750w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_10.webp?width=2100&height=843&name=form-examples_10.webp 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px"></div>
<h3>5. <a href="https://classpass.com/">Class Pass</a></h3>
<p>Allegedly, <a href="http://www.color-wheel-pro.com/color-meaning.html">blue produces a calming effect</a>, which is exactly how I felt checking out Class Pass’s landing page and immediately seeing a blue free trial button. Clearly, they know what I want. Their form is one of the easier ones in the list: it only requires your name, email, and password, or you can sign in via Facebook. Plus, when you fill out the form, you’re immediately gifted with a certain amount of credit, and a message that tells you the average amount of classes you can take in your city with those credits.</p>
<div><img src="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_6.webp?width=349&height=656&name=form-examples_6.webp" width="349" height="656" loading="lazy" alt="web form examples: Facebook" style="width: 349px; display: block; margin: 0px auto; height: auto; max-width: 100%;" srcset="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_6.webp?width=175&height=328&name=form-examples_6.webp 175w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_6.webp?width=349&height=656&name=form-examples_6.webp 349w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_6.webp?width=524&height=984&name=form-examples_6.webp 524w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_6.webp?width=698&height=1312&name=form-examples_6.webp 698w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_6.webp?width=873&height=1640&name=form-examples_6.webp 873w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_6.webp?width=1047&height=1968&name=form-examples_6.webp 1047w" sizes="(max-width: 349px) 100vw, 349px"></div>
<h3>6. <a href="https://www.toptal.com/">Toptal</a></h3>
<p>A form should still abide by quality customer service rules. How can your form be helpful to a potential consumer, without frustrating them with unnecessary questions? Toptal, which helps you find and hire elite independent freelancers, does an incredible job, first by displaying how far along a user is in their form submission (which encourages them to keep going), and second, by incorporating a phone conversation seamlessly into the process.</p>
<p>After answering a few questions, their form concludes with a question: When should we call you? You’re given the option of now or later, and once you’ve answered, the form offers to automatically integrate your scheduled phone call into your Google calendar or iCalendar. Toptal knows its value is better explained via phone, and their form proves they respect your time and don’t want to waste it.</p>
<div><img src="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_5.webp?width=700&height=460&name=form-examples_5.webp" width="700" height="460" loading="lazy" alt="web form examples: Toptal" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; height: auto; max-width: 100%; width: 700px;" srcset="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_5.webp?width=350&height=230&name=form-examples_5.webp 350w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_5.webp?width=700&height=460&name=form-examples_5.webp 700w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_5.webp?width=1050&height=690&name=form-examples_5.webp 1050w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_5.webp?width=1400&height=920&name=form-examples_5.webp 1400w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_5.webp?width=1750&height=1150&name=form-examples_5.webp 1750w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_5.webp?width=2100&height=1380&name=form-examples_5.webp 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px"></div>
<div><img src="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_9.webp?width=700&height=412&name=form-examples_9.webp" width="700" height="412" loading="lazy" alt="web form examples: Toptal 2" style="height: auto; max-width: 100%; width: 700px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;" srcset="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_9.webp?width=350&height=206&name=form-examples_9.webp 350w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_9.webp?width=700&height=412&name=form-examples_9.webp 700w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_9.webp?width=1050&height=618&name=form-examples_9.webp 1050w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_9.webp?width=1400&height=824&name=form-examples_9.webp 1400w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_9.webp?width=1750&height=1030&name=form-examples_9.webp 1750w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_9.webp?width=2100&height=1236&name=form-examples_9.webp 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px"></div>
<h3>7. <a href="https://www.uxpassion.com/">UX Passion</a></h3>
<p>Sometimes you need to ask for more information than just name and email, which can frustrate a user. If you incorporate a message like UX Passion’s -- “The more we know, the more we are able to help” -- it could go a long way towards alleviating that frustration. Their message adds a human element, reminding you that the form fields were chosen as necessary elements to help you, not just to waste your time.</p>
<div><img src="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_1.webp?width=700&height=400&name=form-examples_1.webp" width="700" height="400" loading="lazy" alt="web form examples: UX Passion" style="height: auto; max-width: 100%; width: 700px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;" srcset="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_1.webp?width=350&height=200&name=form-examples_1.webp 350w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_1.webp?width=700&height=400&name=form-examples_1.webp 700w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_1.webp?width=1050&height=600&name=form-examples_1.webp 1050w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_1.webp?width=1400&height=800&name=form-examples_1.webp 1400w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_1.webp?width=1750&height=1000&name=form-examples_1.webp 1750w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_1.webp?width=2100&height=1200&name=form-examples_1.webp 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px"></div>
<h3>8. <a href="https://signup.37signals.com/basecamp/free/">Basecamp Classic</a></h3>
<p>As soon as you arrive at Basecamp Classic’s page, you’re greeted with a form. At the top, the form mentions how long it will take to fill out (60 seconds), and at the bottom, it highlights the benefits of the free plan and promises the trial won’t end. With those statements sandwiching the top and bottom of the form, it’s likely most visitors will fill it out because -- well, why not?</p>
<div><img src="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_12.webp?width=700&height=941&name=form-examples_12.webp" width="700" height="941" loading="lazy" alt="web form examples: Basecamp Classic" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; height: auto; max-width: 100%; width: 700px;" srcset="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_12.webp?width=350&height=471&name=form-examples_12.webp 350w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_12.webp?width=700&height=941&name=form-examples_12.webp 700w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_12.webp?width=1050&height=1412&name=form-examples_12.webp 1050w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_12.webp?width=1400&height=1882&name=form-examples_12.webp 1400w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_12.webp?width=1750&height=2353&name=form-examples_12.webp 1750w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_12.webp?width=2100&height=2823&name=form-examples_12.webp 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px"></div>
<h3>9. <a href="https://www.getharvest.com/">Harvest</a></h3>
<p>There are two reasons I love this form by Harvest: first, it answers my primary concerns upfront -- Will I have to supply a credit card and risk getting charged if I don’t cancel my account? And what am I missing out on with the free version?</p>
<p>The second reason I love the form is the “5 Reasons You’ll Love Harvest” box on the right. The rest of the form is neat and clean, so there’s no confusion about where or what to fill out, but if you begin to waiver, the box on the right is an extra step to ensure you remember why you’re signing up.</p>
<div><img src="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_8.webp?width=700&height=652&name=form-examples_8.webp" width="700" height="652" loading="lazy" alt="web form examples: Harvest" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block; height: auto; max-width: 100%; width: 700px;" srcset="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_8.webp?width=350&height=326&name=form-examples_8.webp 350w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_8.webp?width=700&height=652&name=form-examples_8.webp 700w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_8.webp?width=1050&height=978&name=form-examples_8.webp 1050w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_8.webp?width=1400&height=1304&name=form-examples_8.webp 1400w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_8.webp?width=1750&height=1630&name=form-examples_8.webp 1750w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_8.webp?width=2100&height=1956&name=form-examples_8.webp 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px"></div>
<h3>10. <a href="https://www.comparethemarket.com/">Compare the Market</a></h3>
<p>This is one of the most user-friendly ones in the list, with icons you can hover over to choose A or B, rather than a text field. Best of all, when you hover over an icon like “Yes, I have my bill,” you’re offered an explanation regarding why it’s necessary, and whether you can proceed without it. Plus, the buttons are big and colorful, creating an engaging and visually appealing user experience.</p>
<div><img src="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_3.webp?width=700&height=285&name=form-examples_3.webp" width="700" height="285" loading="lazy" alt="web form examples: Compare the Market" style="height: auto; max-width: 100%; width: 700px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; display: block;" srcset="https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_3.webp?width=350&height=143&name=form-examples_3.webp 350w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_3.webp?width=700&height=285&name=form-examples_3.webp 700w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_3.webp?width=1050&height=428&name=form-examples_3.webp 1050w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_3.webp?width=1400&height=570&name=form-examples_3.webp 1400w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_3.webp?width=1750&height=713&name=form-examples_3.webp 1750w, https://www.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/form-examples_3.webp?width=2100&height=855&name=form-examples_3.webp 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px"></div>
<p>If you’re still unsure which direction you need to take your online forms to make your buyer happiest, try A/B testing one of these elements at a time. Ultimately, your form is a method to interact with your customers, so it should be thoughtful, relatively easy, and a strong reflection of your brand.</p>
<p><!--HubSpot Call-to-Action Code --><span class="hs-cta-wrapper" id="hs-cta-wrapper-ed056a26-dd56-4392-b117-430e200628c4"><span class="hs-cta-node hs-cta-ed056a26-dd56-4392-b117-430e200628c4" id="hs-cta-ed056a26-dd56-4392-b117-430e200628c4" style="visibility: visible;"><!--[if lte IE 8]><div id="hs-cta-ie-element"></div><![endif]--><a href="https://cta-redirect.hubspot.com/cta/redirect/53/ed056a26-dd56-4392-b117-430e200628c4" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img class="hs-cta-img" id="hs-cta-img-ed056a26-dd56-4392-b117-430e200628c4" style="border-width:0px;margin: 0 auto; display: block; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px" height="226" width="646" src="https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/ed056a26-dd56-4392-b117-430e200628c4.png" alt="The Ultimate Guide to Web Forms — Download Now." align="middle"></a></span><script charset="utf-8" src="/hs/cta/cta/current.js" nonce=""></script><script type="text/javascript" nonce=""> hbspt.cta._relativeUrls=true;hbspt.cta.load(53, 'ed056a26-dd56-4392-b117-430e200628c4', {"useNewLoader":"true","region":"na1"}); </script></span><!-- end HubSpot Call-to-Action Code --></p>

  <style>@keyframes msf-progress {
  0% {
    transform: scaleX(0);
    opacity: 0;
  }

  100% {
    transform: scaleX(1);
    opacity: 1;
  }
}

@keyframes msf-appear {
  0% {
    scale: 0;
  }

  100% {
    scale: 1;
  }
}

.msf-container {
  --rff-indicator-outline-color: var(--light-theme-background-01);
  --rff-indicator-incomplete-background-color: var(--cl-color-container-03);
  --rff-indicator-complete-background-color: var(--cl-color-success-01);
  --rff-indicator-incomplete-text-color: var(--cl-color-text-01);
  --rff-indicator-complete-text-color: var(--cl-color-text-on-color-01);
  --rff-indicator-incomplete-border-color: var(--cl-color-border-03);
  --rff-indicator-complete-border-color: transparent;

  margin: 0 auto;
  max-width: 720px;
  container-name: msf-container;
  container-type: inline-size;

  &.-dark {
    --rff-indicator-outline-color: var(--dark-theme-background-02);
  }
}

.msf-header {
  text-align: center;
  margin: 2em 0 0 0;
}

.msf-progress-bar {
  position: absolute;
  z-index: 0;
  top: 50%;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  transform: translateY(-50%) scaleX(0);
  opacity: 0;
  height: 2px;
  background-color: var(--gray-30);
  transform-origin: left;
}

.msf-container[data-show-steps='true'] .msf-progress-bar {
  animation: msf-progress 1s linear forwards;
}

.msf-progress-header {
  position: relative;
  max-width: 860px;
  margin: 1rem auto 2.5rem;
}

.msf-indicators {
  list-style: none;
  width: 100%;
  display: flex;
  justify-content: space-between;
  flex-direction: row;
}

.msf-indicator {
  position: relative;
  z-index: 1;
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
  align-items: center;
  width: 2rem;
  height: 2rem;
  color: var(--rff-indicator-incomplete-text-color);
  background-color: var(--rff-indicator-incomplete-background-color);
  border: 2px solid var(--rff-indicator-incomplete-border-color);
  border-radius: 50%;
  outline: 8px solid var(--rff-indicator-outline-color);
  scale: 0;
  transition: 0.3s background-color linear;
  font-size: var(--font-size-h6, 1rem);
  font-weight: var(--font-weight-h6, 500);
  line-height: var(--line-height-h6, 1.75);
}

.msf-indicator .cl-icon {
  display: none;
}

.msf-container[data-show-steps='true'] .msf-indicator {
  animation: msf-appear 0.3s ease-out forwards;
  animation-delay: var(--delay);
}

.msf-indicator.complete,
.msf-indicator.active {
  background-color: var(--rff-indicator-complete-background-color);
  color: var(--rff-indicator-complete-text-color);
  border-color: var(--rff-indicator-complete-border-color);
}

.msf-indicator.complete .cl-icon {
  height: 1rem;
  width: 1rem;
  position: absolute;
  fill: currentColor;
  display: flex;
}

.msf-indicator.complete > span {
  opacity: 0; /* effectively visually-hidden */
}

.msf {
  --current-step: 1;
  position: relative;
  margin: 0 auto;
  max-width: 1080px;
  overflow: hidden;
}

.msf-list {
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  flex-wrap: nowrap;
  width: 100%;
  list-style: none;
  transform: translateX(calc(-100% * (var(--current-step) - 1)));
  transition: transform 0.35s ease-in-out;
}

.msf-step {
  width: 100%;
  min-width: 100%;
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: center;
  visibility: hidden;
}

.msf-step[data-active='true'] {
  visibility: visible;
}

.msf-step-fields {
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
}

@container msf-container (width >= 600px) {
  .msf-step-fields {
    flex-direction: row;
  }
}

.msf-field + .msf-field {
  padding-top: 1.5rem;
}

@container msf-container (width >= 600px) {
  .msf-field + .msf-field {
    padding-left: 1.5rem;
    padding-top: 0;
  }
}

.msf-legal {
  max-height: 0;
  overflow: hidden;
  transition: max-height 0.5s ease-in;
  text-align: left;
  font-size: var(--font-size-small);
  line-height: var(--line-height-small);
}

.msf-legal > p {
  font-size: var(--font-size-small);
  line-height: var(--line-height-small);
}

.msf-navigation {
  position: relative;
  width: 100%;
  display: flex;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: space-between;
  padding-top: 2rem;
}

.msf-next {
  position: relative;
}

.msf-submit {
  position: absolute;
  right: 0;
  visibility: hidden;
}

.msf[data-step='1'] .msf-previous {
  visibility: hidden;
}

.msf[data-last-step='true'] .msf-next {
  visibility: hidden;
}

.msf[data-last-step='true'] .msf-submit {
  visibility: visible;
}

.msf[data-last-step='true'] .msf-legal {
  max-height: 100vh;
}

/* Component library validation */
.msf .cl-input .cl-input-status {
  display: none;
}

.msf .cl-input.-invalid .cl-input-status {
  display: unset;
}

/* Loading states for CTAs */
.msf .cl-button {
  min-height: 41px;
}

.msf .cl-loading {
  position: absolute;
  display: none;
  top: 50%;
  left: 50%;
  transform: translate(-50%, -50%);
}

.msf-submit.loading > span,
.msf-next.loading > span {
  visibility: hidden;
}

.msf-submit.loading > .cl-loading,
.msf-next.loading > .cl-loading {
  display: block;
}
